content.html:
hey @Addisu Z. Taddese any idea what's going on with this test failure:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/2109/testReport/(root)/PhysicsSystemFixture/MultiAxisJointPosition/

it's failing consistently on Ubuntu and homebrew

content.raw: This seems to be related to the [Detachable Joint PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/102/). I ran the test with the `ign-physics1` branch and it passes.
content.html: This seems to be related to the Detachable Joint PR. I ran the test with the ign-physics1 branch and it passes.

content.raw:
The issue is that this test loads a model that has a Gearbox joint, which is currently not supported in DART. Previously, a fixed joint was created, but with the changes in [ign-physics PR #102](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/102/), an invalid entity is created because a Gearbox joint (at least, the way it's setup in the model) forms a kinematic loop. We have a few of options:

* Comment out the gearbox joint in the test model. This would fix the test, but if anyone runs a world that contains a gearbox joint, it could crash ign-gazebo.
* Check if a joint is valid in the physics system before adding it to the std::map that couples ign-gazebo joints with ign-physics joints. 
* Check if a joint type is supported in ign-gazebo before calling `ConstructJoint`. Maybe, change the joint type to `fixed` if it is not supported.
content.html:
The issue is that this test loads a model that has a Gearbox joint, which is currently not supported in DART. Previously, a fixed joint was created, but with the changes in ign-physics PR #102, an invalid entity is created because a Gearbox joint (at least, the way it's setup in the model) forms a kinematic loop. We have a few of options:

  • Comment out the gearbox joint in the test model. This would fix the test, but if anyone runs a world that contains a gearbox joint, it could crash ign-gazebo.
  • Check if a joint is valid in the physics system before adding it to the std::map that couples ign-gazebo joints with ign-physics joints.
  • Check if a joint type is supported in ign-gazebo before calling ConstructJoint. Maybe, change the joint type to fixed if it is not supported.

content.raw: option 2 sounds right to me
content.html: option 2 sounds right to me

content.raw: since gearbox joints aren't supported yet anyway
content.html: since gearbox joints aren't supported yet anyway

content.raw: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/438/avoid-using-invalid-unsupported-joints
content.html: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/438/avoid-using-invalid-unsupported-joints

I tried adding the following, but it causes other failures now. Does returning false in that EachNew callback stop other joint initialization from happening?

diff -r 12ea93fa1666 src/systems/physics/Physics.cc
--- a/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc    Tue Oct 15 17:18:16 2019 -0700
+++ b/src/systems/physics/Physics.cc    Wed Oct 16 13:58:25 2019 -0700
@@ -554,6 +554,13 @@
         // Use the parent link's parent model as the model of this joint
         auto jointPtrPhys = modelPtrPhys->ConstructJoint(joint);

+        if (!jointPtrPhys)
+        {
+          ignerr << "Failed to load joint of name [" << _name->Data()
+                 << "]." << std::endl;
+          return false;
+        }
+
         this->entityJointMap.insert(std::make_pair(_entity, jointPtrPhys));
         return true;
       });

https://gist.github.com/scpeters/ed6770fa21147bfdf1699b5b4698d169

content.raw:
I’m seeing a lot of code here related to distinguishing between relative vs absolute path names.

Since `ign-gazebo` is using C\+\+17, why not use the standard library tools: [https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/path/is\_absrel](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/path/is_absrel)
content.html:
I’m seeing a lot of code here related to distinguishing between relative vs absolute path names.

Since ign-gazebo is using C++17, why not use the standard library tools: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem/path/is_absrel

content.raw:
`std::filesystem` isn't supported by the version of Xcode in macOS 10.14 (mojave), so we haven't been using that part of c++17 yet

it is available in macOS 10.15 (catalina), so we could consider using it if we get our CI machines upgraded
content.html:
std::filesystem isn't supported by the version of Xcode in macOS 10.14 (mojave), so we haven't been using that part of c++17 yet

it is available in macOS 10.15 (catalina), so we could consider using it if we get our CI machines upgraded

content.raw: What about using it for non-macOS platforms? It seems there are already special precompiler exceptions for Windows, so maybe those special exceptions can use `std::filesystem` inside of them instead of hardcoding things like `C:\`.
content.html: What about using it for non-macOS platforms? It seems there are already special precompiler exceptions for Windows, so maybe those special exceptions can use std::filesystem inside of them instead of hardcoding things like C:\.

content.raw: that's a decent idea, then once we start using `std::filesystem` on all platforms we can just delete the other ifdef block
content.html: that's a decent idea, then once we start using std::filesystem on all platforms we can just delete the other ifdef block

content.raw:
@{557058:90bc87b0-2886-4377-a17c-3a6629a697ff} , on 6c16188 I made sure that relative paths from Unix work on Windows and vice-versa. There's a TODO left for supporting absolute paths interchangeably, but I think that using an absolute path from another machine is not a good idea, let alone from another operating system.

If the tests pass on Windows and you agree with the latest changes, feel free to merge.
content.html:
@Addisu Z. Taddese , on 6c16188 I made sure that relative paths from Unix work on Windows and vice-versa. There's a TODO left for supporting absolute paths interchangeably, but I think that using an absolute path from another machine is not a good idea, let alone from another operating system.

If the tests pass on Windows and you agree with the latest changes, feel free to merge.
